Award.AwardTitle: Symposium KK: Biomaterials for Tissue Regeneration; Boston, MA; November 28 - December 2, 2011
Award.AbstractNarration:
ID: MPS/DMR/BMAT(7623) 1154940 PI: Wolf, Sandra ORG: Materials Research Society

Title: Support for Fall 2011 MRS Symposium Biomaterials for Tissue Regeneration

INTELLECTUAL MERIT: Tissue engineering is an emerging field, which has major potential to improve human health by repairing and maintaining existing organs or regenerating new ones. This potential can be realized through a combination of a scaffold matrix, progenitor cells, and/or bioactive agents to form a tissue engineering construct to promote organ repair. Biomaterials play a crucial role in tissue regeneration. Although technical advances have been made, success to date has been limited due to current lack of understanding of the regenerative process in native tissues, the complexity of the 3D environment, and our ability to identify and recapitulate the appropriate cues that promote functional cellular and tissue growth. Understanding and utilization of tissue engineering scaffolds, scaffold-biomaterials interactions, and in vivo scaffold performance are central to tissue engineering and regenerative medicine and are closely related to the scientific interests in the Biomaterials Program (DMR) at the National Science Foundation.

BROADER IMPACTS: The aim of this symposium is to collect and present a broad range of areas in biomaterials developments for regenerative medicine and to stimulate innovative research ideas among scientists and researchers from different disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The “Biomaterials for Tissue Regeneration” symposium was well-received and each lecture had a good turnout that filled the room. The invited lectures drew from world experts including Robert Langer (MIT), Cato Laurencin (UConn), David Kaplan (Tufts), William Reichert (Duke),

The joint session on Cell-Biomaterial Interactions with the Multifunctional Polymer-based Materials Symposium (V) was also particularly popular. One of our symposium graduate students was a MRS silver award recipient and we awarded 7 additional NSF-sponsored student awards (1 to an undergraduate student, 5 to graduate students, and 1 to a postdoc). One award was presented from each of the oral and poster sessions of our symposium. The topics discussed at the symposium were broad and ranged from the design and synthesis of novel biological materials, to single molecule force measurements and mechanistic studies of material-cell interactions, to characterization of material properties, to interaction of biomaterials including scaffolds with cells in vitro, to in vivo studies of biomaterials in model animal systems. The consensus of the presentations and discussions was that tissue regeneration is complex and requires insights and interdisciplinary research from material scientists, developmental biologists, engineers, and clinicians who work together. Advances in areas such as microfabrication, shape-memory materials, conducting polymers, andscaffold design were also shown to be promising avenues to the future of the field of tissue regeneration.

Mário Barbosa (Univ. do Porto, Portugal), Andreas Lendlein (Helmholtz-Zentrum Geesthacht,Germany), Charles Sorrell (Univ. of New South Wales, Australia), David Rowe (UConn),Kaiming Ye (Univ. Arkansas), and Ali Khademhosseini (Harvard) were well-attended, and there was good audience participation. In addition, the symposium also attracted highly experienced senior scientists from industry, including Wendell Sun (LifeCell) and Tim Sargeant (Covidien) as our invited speakers and James Olson (Teleflex Medical Inc.) as one of the organizers of the Symposium.


Last Modified: 10/30/2012
Modified by: Sandra Devincent Wolf
